posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked:
Hi There, I’m a student member from team 2359, and I’m hoping to grow my teams CAD resources over my time on the team.

My team only uses CAD for designing select parts for CNC milling and 3D printing, but my hope is that our team can CAD our whole robot by the time I become a senior. However, only me and two of our mentors tend to use CAD, so I will have to teach my team anything I learn.

I am additionally still new to CAD.

My request is for advice, custom functions, resources, and tools that can aid my team in using Onshape for FRC .

(I am already using online resources and tools from Onshape4Frc and similar online tools)

Thank you in advance, and sincerely,

Davion from 2359

posts.name: Ari Davidson
posts.cooked: https://www.frcdesign.org/ is a really great resource if you aren’t already using it!

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked:
Thank you, I had been planning on looking at it while at home, since it’s blocked on the computers from our schools, but had completely forgotten!!!

I’ll remember to use it now, so thanks!

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: You could look at onshape4frc.com in addition to frcdesign.org .  It may have a few additional references.

posts.name: Benjamen Johnson
posts.cooked:
Look at the slideshow on this thread:

CMP Conference Slides - Onshape Best Practices for FRC Design Technical

I didn’t attend this seminar this year, but it appears very close to last year when I did. There are a lot of good tips for organizing your robot and keeping the CAD speedy.

link_counts.title: CMP Conference Slides - Onshape Best Practices for FRC Design

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked: Okay, that looks really interesting, I’ll look into it. Thanks!!!

posts.name: Andrew Card
posts.cooked: Might be worth a shot reaching out to your schools admin to see if they cant whitelist the site.

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked:
Thank you! I hadn’t considered that yet.

I will certainly try. I have quite a few websites I need whitelisted, but our admin is stingy sometimes.

posts.name: Colin
posts.cooked:
My team uses FRCDesign for training because it goes over everything you need to know to have good/clean CAD for a FRC robot.

For tools we use the MKCad Library for importing COTS parts. Along with quite a few Featurescripts that are linked on FRCDesign.

If you have any questions I’d be happy to provide more information.

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked:
Thank you for your reply!!! I will look into FRCDesign, most definitely. Just working out it being blocked on school Chromebooks.

I’ll look into the featurescripts included as well, so thank you.

I’m curious about how your team organizes projects in Onshape for collaboration between members? We currently have a classroom or a team set up, but when a student adds a document, no other students can see it, just the classroom leader.

posts.name: Colin
posts.cooked:
Right now we have a team set up that we have shared to our design team and any other members that need it.

We plan to have a team account with the school where we are thinking of setting up a classroom to make document ownership easier because right now we our old team is owned by one of our Alumi on there school email and we want to be able to make sure all of docs are managed well and we don’t risk them getting deleted. I’m not sure is that’s what you were asking but I can clarify further if needed.

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked: That answers my question perfectly, thank you!

posts.name: Colin
posts.cooked: Of course!! Let me know if you have any other questions.

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: The other Advantage to using a Classroom is that it allows members to use other features, such as simulation and release management.

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked:
Is that included with the free education stuff?

Just curious, I know we’re missing out on some of the professional features because we’re using free student and educator accounts.

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked:
This blog details the benefits of using an Educator plan and also explains how to set it up: Onshape Educator Plan for FIRST Robotics Teams

The most important reason is it can stop situations where students graduate and leave with previous designs the team wants to retain.

link_counts.title: Onshape Educator Plan for FIRST Robotics Teams

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: Check out this thread: https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/onshape-educator-plan-what-it-means-for-frc-teams/446394

link_counts.title: Onshape Educator Plan: What it Means for FRC Teams

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked: Okay, thank you!!! I’m reading through it currently. I believe our mentor has an educator plan, however I don’t think we’ve used many of it’s capabilities. The blog has a lot of good info

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked:
I’m reading through this as well!! Thanks!!!

(Is it mere coincidence that the writer of that thread also just sent a message? If so, that’s really cool)

posts.name: Julian Fernandez
posts.cooked: Frcdesign covers pretty much all you will need, but I’ll still say a few words. Sketches are everything, do not underestimate what you can do with good in-sketch skills. It may not be very exciting, but it’s the foundation of everything that comes after. I’m not sure what level you are on, but just try to make your sketches clean and organized, don’t close a sketch if there are still blue lines. Then work on features, try to use as few as possible and a variety, seeing extrude 1-20 is usually not the correct way to make a part. Then look though featurescripts, some are not really useful, but some will save you hours of sanity. Try to make a library of the ones you use most and make them part of your workflow. Then during the season, design under what you think your capabilities are. Being the design lead when overscoped is one of the worst things ever
